did.physloc: Portions of the collection are located offsite; two days notice required for retrieval.
did.abstract: Ann Arbor, Michigan attorney, member of the University of Michigan Board of Regents, 1975-1990, and Democratic Party official. Papers document his activities as regent and in local and state-wide Democratic Party affairs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The papers were donated by to the library by Thomas A. Roach (donor no. 7613) in 1991 and 1997. Additional materials came to the library in 2002.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been retained by the donor until February 25, 2041.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Thomas Roach Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan.

bioghist.p: Thomas A. Roach is an attorney, an active participant within the Michigan Democratic party, and an elected public official. Born in Akron, Ohio on May 1, 1929, Roach graduated from the University of Michigan Law School in 1953. He commenced the practice of law in Detroit, Michigan, and eventually became partner in different Detroit and Ann Arbor law firms.

Beginning in the early 1970s, Roach began taking an active leadership role in local and statewide Democratic politics. Locally, from 1971 to 1975, he served as vice chairman of the 14th Congressional District Democratic Organization. Within the state party organization, he served in numerous positions, including chairman of the platform and resolution committee (1971-1974); party treasurer (1975-1987); and as convention parliamentarian and a member of various committees. In 1975, Roach ran successfully for public office as a regent of the University of Michigan and served in this position until 1990.

scopecontent.p: The papers of Thomas Roach measure fifty-four linear feet and date from 1970 to 2002. These records document the public career of Roach as a Regent of the University of Michigan and a longtime active participant in the Michigan Democratic Party. The papers are divided into three series: Democratic Party Files, Board of Regents Files and Post-Regental Activities.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Disinvestment--South Africa.
Investments, American--South Africa.
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Board of Regents.

scopecontent.p: The five linear feet of Democratic Party Files are arranged alphabetically by topic and reflect Roach's activities within this organization. The substantial "Party Leadership" files contain meeting agendas, memoranda, and correspondence of the party officers. The "Budgets" files contains financial records of the party, stemming from Roach's tenure as treasurer. The "Reapportionment" files relates to congressional redistricting in Michigan following the 1980 census. Other policy issues covered in these papers include "No Fault Legislation," "the "Bingo Tax Issue," and "Election Data Services." Many of the other files in this series concern Roach's participation in different Democratic Party committees, groups, and events. Of these, the "Rules Committee of the Democratic National Convention" files are the most significant and provide information both on the committee and the specific role Roach played in it.

did.unittitle: Democratic Club of Grosse Point Park, Michigan 1970-1974
Final Plans (Senate and House of Representatives)
Rules Committee of the Democratic National Convention 1980
State and district convention files (mainly relating to work with party platform and resolution committee)
Campaign for U-M Board of Regents

scopecontent.p: Board of Regents Files primarily document Roach's activity in his capacity as Regent of the University of Michigan and are divided into five subseries: Correspondence, Roach for Regent, Speeches, Topical Files, and Regents' Agendas and Exhibits.

The Correspondence subseries contains both official and informal communications to and from Roach. Many letters serve as petitions to Regent Roach and therefore reflect the concerns and praises of individual citizens and groups about the functioning of the university. Much correspondence between Roach and university officials, including other regents, the university president, and other executive officers comprise a large amount of this subseries. Also included are some memoranda addressed collectively to the Board of Regents from the executive officers of the university, especially the Office of the President, but researchers should also consult the record groups for those university offices for more extensive coverage of the issues discussed in these communications.

The Roach for Regent subseries contains campaign materials from Roach's unsuccessful bid for election in 1972 and his successful re-election in 1982. The bulk of these materials document the 1982 campaign. There is, unfortunately, little information on Roach's first successful campaign in 1975. The "Biographical Information" file in this subseries includes a vitae for Roach along with other materials illuminating his life, and "Candidate Questionnaires" from both 1972 and 1982 provide information on his political views.

The Speech subseries contains notes for speeches Roach made while a Regent along with information on the venue or audience. The file is arranged alphabetically by place and event, and titles and dates have been provided where discernible. The full text of the speech "Allocation of Scarce Medical Resources" is included in the "Conference on Ethics, Humanism, and Medicine" file.

did.unittitle: Conference on Ethics, Humanism, and Medicine, November 11, 1978. ("Allocation of Scarce Medical Resources")
Farm and Industrial Equipment Institute May 22, 1980
Oakland University December 6, 1978 (University of Michigan South Africa Investment Policy)
School Of Music Honors Assembly April 7, 1981 ("Excellence in the 80s at Michigan")
Torch Club of Detroit January 20, 1983 ("A Regent Looks at Higher Education")
University of Michigan-Dearborn Library Dedication April 11, 1981

scopecontent.p: Measuring more than three linear feet and arranged alphabetically, the Topical subseries documents regental activity in which Roach was particularly active. The records in this subseries are diverse and include correspondence, memoranda, reports, meeting agendas, and other miscellanea relating to a specific topic. Included are files relating to the "Campaign for Michigan"and the University of Michigan's South Africa Investment Policy. The "Campaign for Michigan" files include records from a major university fund-raising campaign for which Roach served as National Coordinator for Special Gifts. Roach also played a major role in the debates of the late 1970s and early 1980s over the appropriateness the university's investments in South Africa. The records in the "South Africa Investment Policy" files provide excellent documentation of the issues and events surrounding this debate and of Roach's participation in them. Of special interest is the "Indicia of Excellence" file consisting of reports from the different schools, colleges, and departments within the university on what they believed to be the finest aspects of their units. Finally, the records in the "Commission on the Future of Higher Education" files offer excellent documentation of Roach's participation on this important state board.

scopecontent.p: The final subseries - Regents' Agendas and Exhibits - forms the bulk of the collection and includes materials distributed to each regent at their monthly meetings. These files are of interest because of Roach's occasional marginal notes. This subseries covers the period of 1974 to 1990 and should be consulted in conjunction with the library's other holdings of Regents' Agendas and Exhibits (filed in the catalog as University of Michigan. Board of Regents).
